LBX is Gundam meets Pokemon or as close to that as you can get. You play as a 13 year old boy who is trying to become the best LBX player. LBX are small robots people use for battles.

column13: Excellent Warranty Service (and Longer Than Listed)
column14:
It works just as well as the official Xbox controller. It glows in the dark, so I can switch off all the lights and plays games in a dark room. But you know that already. So I am gonna tell you about my experience with the customer service and warranty.

I think the warranty period for this controller is 90 days or something. (Most game controllers and mice have three to six month warranty.) I think I bought this controller in May 2014, and its A-button broke in November 2014. The internal spring of the A-button had lost its elasticity. When I pressed the A-button, it would stay down and not bounce back up promptly. That is a very common problem with the A-button because it is the one that is repeatedly pressed and abused the most. So I called up the manufacturer, knowing that the warranty period had expired. I had to call a few times because no one picked up the phone during the first few calls. column13: Replaced my Gamepad in a Heartbeat
column14:
The build quality of this remote is excellent. There's a little give to the buttons, but everything feels spectacular and solid in the hand. It works as expected, and I've been using this as my main remote on my Nvidia Shield TV even though I'm a gamer - it's so convenient, it replaced the gamepad in a heartbeat. The coolest bit? Sue me, but it's the glowing microphone button. It just looks so damn cool. Being able to plug your headphones into the bottom is a close second.

I do have a few minor gripes with the controller. None of them bother me too much, but your mileage may vary.
1. Plastic parts get micro scratches easily, as does all plastic
2. I can't confidently grip this remote as I'm watching stuff on my TV, since the volume control is touch sensitive. Grip it too hard and your volume will start changing.
3. When I plug in my headphones to the port, it comes out relatively easily. There's no "click" or light lock to keep it in there.
4. No dedicated media control buttons. The layout is nice and as an artist who can appreciate simplicity and design, I get why they omitted it. But still, having forward/backward/play buttons would be much more convenient. Fast-forward and rewind is easily one of the biggest inconveniences on Android TV. The difference between using a touch screen to drag a slider vs holding a button to FF (or worse, select 4x speed like on DVD)players) is night and day.

Overall it's a solid remote. The complains I have are mostly informative, so you know exactly what you're getting into. My experience with it has been great, and with the $25 promotion I would say it's a necessity to complement your Shield TV.

column13: Elder Scrolls Fan Fiction in MMO form
column14: I'm going to start off by saying that this is by no means a bad game; in fact, it's quite excellent for an MMO and as taken at face value. Where it goes wrong, I feel, is the Elder Scrolls part of it.  Notice that the game is made by Zenimax and not Bethesa Game Studios (Bethseda Softworks own both). They did as good of a job as they could, but it comes off almost as a fan fiction rendering of the series. I can't help but think while playing it that there's no way that this game will be considered part of the Elder Scrolls canon when they make the next single player ES RPG. Keep in mind while reading my review, that a lot of what I'm talking about was *not* explained in-game and that I figured out a lot of this based upon googling and just playing. It made the experience a little more frustrating than it had to be.  I started as a Nord in the Ebonheart Pact. Just like the other games, you have a choice of the various races (except Imperial class which you have to unlock) and you have a choice between the three alliances. The latter choice will set you in one world until you hit level 50 (in my case, so far, I have access to Dark Elf settlements, argonian areas, and nord areas as well as bits of skyrim here and there) and after that you have to clear the other two in order to complete the game. Once you hit level 10 you have access to the PvP section in Cyrodil, which I haven't much explored yet, but it seems you can become Emperor if you have the highest score on the winning team, which opens up a unique emperor skill tree. The premise, which is not intuitive at all, has you begin in ColdHarbour, the realm of the Daedric prince, Molag Baal. You learn that you are dead, that your soul removed was from your body, and that your goal, effectively, is to stop Molag Baal from breaking through into this world and to get your soul back. Back in Nirn, 1,000 years before the events of Skyrim, there is civil war brewing and the races are forming alliances that are competing for the throne as well as for control over all Tamriel.  THE GOOD: - It's addicting. Though my "bad" section seems to override the good, the only reason for that is because they chose to call this an Elder Scrolls game when they could have easily used the same exact system to create another MMO. It gets better as you play it.  - The main storyline, thus far (I'm at lvl 15), is pretty good. Not up to par with the previous titles but very good for the MMO genre. The main story, the guild storylines, and the overarching war lines are all good. It's the billions of random other ones that are a bit boring and come off pointless. I don't really care about most of the characters because they don't have any distinguishing characteristics or quirks that would make them interesting; all are cookie-cutter versions of each other and each race is a bit of a caricature. Despite that, still enjoyable overall.  - I like that the best way to level up is to complete quests. It just works well for this game.  - The multi-player integration is great too. I thought I'd hate it, but it was a bit fun to pair up with randoms for multiple person dungeons. It can be annoying at times when another player or players beat the boss just as you get there. You get credit for beating the boss without even throwing a punch. When that happens you have to be careful because sometimes when picking up whatever it is you needed from the boss, it respawns and starts hitting you. Hope they fix that. There are annoying sorts - children playing loud music, squeaky mics, domestic disputes - but you can always just leave the chat channel or the chat area. It's pretty much impossible for someone to ruin the experience for you, which is a nice touch.  THE BAD: -It's technically not free. You have to pay for a playstation plus subscription. I just paid for 3 months for $18, and given that, you get game discounts and free game downloads; it's really not that bad price-wise, but it is important to state thatdespite removing their subscription fee, it's still not free to play on consoles.  - The game is all in real time, so there is no saving or pausing. The no pausing drives me crazy because even when you're looking at your inventory or map, things/people can hurt and kill you. When you die, you have a choice to go to the nearest wayshrine or respawn using a full soul gem corresponding to your level. Also, the game logs you out after 20 minutes of inactivity.  - As mentioned, the fast travel system needs a bit of work. It's not intuitive and the PvP and PvE are not mutually compatible for fast travel, which is understandable, but there is no real instruction on how to travel to Cyrodil once you hit level 10 and it's a bit tricky to get back to the PvE engine from Cyrodil (I had to google this and look at multiple places before I figured it out).  - The leveling system, though I've heard that they've fix a few issues, is still ridiculous. What I dislike most about it is that there is no way really to get ahead with super cool armor or a cool rare weapon - every object is given a 'level' and you cannot use, equip, eat or drink anything that is above your level. I've gone ahead and completed quests that were way out of my skill range, received the rewards, only to just drop them off at the bank for storage until I hit that level. This also gives us no incentive to keep or store lower-ranked objects no matter what they are. I just destroy the objects below my ranking because there's no point.  - I feel no incentive to learn enchanting as you can easily find enchanted objects throughout the world. All the other skills such as provisioning, alchemy, woodwork, blacksmithing, leatherwork, etc are pretty boring, unnecessarily complicated, and it seems like everything is made at a much lower level than I'm at (since each of these traits have their own levels/skill trees). It makes it feel pointless, but then again, I haven't really been spending my precious skill points on any of these skills because as a non-subscriber, you don't get them very often.  - Every time you level up, complete a major quest, or collect 3 skyshards you get 1 skill point to spend. Those skills points can be used to purchase special moves, 'ultimate' abilities, or passive traits. There are a ton of skill trees, but when you don't have a subscription it takes a bit longer to level up, which makes it feel incredible slow and monotonous at times. When purchasing special moves for a weapon type (they have bow (all have infinity arrows), 1 hand/shield, dual wielding, two handed, and staff), you assign each move to a button on your controller. The fighting system is a little boring at times because you cannot do what i like to do, which is sneak around and pick people off, not only because of the system but because it seems like enemies respawn in the exact area within a minute (sometimes out of thin air which is annoying). As a lvl 15, I've unlocked weapon swapping but i haven't really utilized this yet.  - Graphics are cartoonish and disappointing in the context of next-gen tech.   - Both jumping and interacting are through the X button, meaning that if there is an interactable object in front of you, you will interact with the object instead of jumping. This was irritating when my character would get stuck between solid objects and I couldn't jump away because there was a damn crate in front of me.   - One of my favorite things about the ES games was that everything was interactable and the stories/characterization were always consistent. In this game, they've simplified its interactiveness. An example would be that you can only read one book from each bookshelf, each container if not empty has one random item in it, potions are just simply marked "alchemy bottle" or "drink," you cannot see the stats for the weapons/armor laying around the world  without picking it up, and most items/dead people are non-interactable. There is literally no way to tell which items you can pick up or not unless you get close to them. As for the inconsistent characterizations/stories, it feels like a fanfiction. Playing in Ebonheart pact, I've noticed they've just pretty much thrown in flora/fauna from other games haphazardly. There is scathcrow all over the place (instead of just being near the volcanic/dark elf areas), there are the large Telvanni mushrooms all over the place (even though the lore states that they're special to that house of dark elves), every Argonian has a hypenated name, and every Nord is a boisterous drunk. Sounds a bit nitpicky,I know, but its those attention to details that really made me fall in love with the previous titles.  OVERALL:  NOT A BAD GAME. It is enjoyable for what it is and the ES title is what is going to get people to buy it. If you are an MMO fan, you will love this. If you are an Elder Scrolls fan, it could go either way. I play video games for storyline and immersion, so my gripes will not be the same as other people's gripes. I'd suggest people at least try it. I didn't like it at all at first, but as I'm cheap, I kept on playing and it sort of grew on me.

column13: Just what the doctor ordered (sort of)
column14:
After playing a mentally exhausting game like Bloodborne, I needed something 'light' to hold me over until Mad Max comes out. LEGO Marvel fit the bill, and was just what the doctor ordered.

Combat -- Well, the type of combat really hinges on who you're playing as. Guys like Iron Man (easily my favorite hero to play with in the game) are better suited to use ranged attacks. However, if you're playing as Hulk or Thing, melee combat is pretty much your only option. If I can be honest, the combat isn't really fun, regardless of who you're playing as. It's a LEGO game, so I wasn't expecting much anyway. As for dodging or blocking incoming attacks; again, it depends on who you're playing as. If you're Captain America, you can use your shield to send projectiles flying back at the enemy. There's not a button dedicated to dodging, so if you're not playing as a character that has a shield, you'll be S.O.L. in some cases. Not to worry though, I pretty much went through the entire game without dying. Now that I think about it, I'm not sure you -can- die...

Weaponry -- I know I sound like a broken record, but it depends on which character you're playing as. I'm not super familiar with the Marvel characters, so I'm not going to attempt to name all of these guys and their powers. If you're a Marvel fan, I'm pretty sure they have the same powers that they have in the comic books and movies. Captain America has his shield, Thor has his hammer, Storm uses her tornado, etc. I didn't play as too many different characters, so I only know of a couple of guys that can use the environment as a weapon, and that would be Hulk and Thing. I wish more characters could make use of the environment, such as the gameplay in Ultimate Alliance II. Oh my, I can't believe I just said something good about that game. I must not be feeling well...

Enemies -- None of the enemies are difficult, and they're not very diverse. There are a few that use projectiles, but most of them just run at you and hit you. The heck with it, I'm just going to come out and say it. You can probably beat most of the enemies with your eyes closed. I found most of the boss battles to be pretty lame, except for the one against my favorite villain :-) Alright, here's how most of the boss battles go:
1) Destroy a fixture of LEGOs.
2) Use the scattered LEGOs to build a new LEGO fixture.
3) Use said fixture of LEGOs as a weapon against the boss, and he'll lose 1 heart of health.
4) Repeat steps 1-3 until you deplete all of their hearts.
This process is actually more lame than it sounds...

Miscellaneous -- If you decide to play through the story mode and skip all of side-missions, it's probably a 15 hour game, at the most. There are a ton of side-missions, but I can't really speak to how much fun they are, because I only completed 2 of them. After completing a level, you'll automatically unlock free-play, which means you can replay the level and use any of the unlocked characters. Although this game is lacking in a lot of areas, it excels in providing challenging puzzles. I hate to admit this, but I relied on YouTube to aid me in a couple of puzzles, so beware. column13: A Rewarding and Replayable RPG (but not for the faint of heart!)
column14:
A challenging, unique, and absorbing twist on the high fantasy RPG formula, The Witcher 2 revels in both rich world-building and inventive gameplay encounters.

As Geralt of Rivia, a seasoned monster hunter with a case of amnesia and nasty habit of falling in with dangerous company, players are thrust into a riveting story of their own choosing: shades of revenge-drama, political thriller, and good ol' fashion mythical questing flesh out Geralt's search for his past and redemption. Cut into four distinctive and diverging chapters based off players' choices in-game, Geralt's journey stretches from lushly detailed forests to war ravaged wastelands, each of which hold beasts waiting to be felled and hugely entertaining side-quests to be completed.

Combat is tactical and quite rewarding given patience and strategy. Slicing and dicing baddies, then breaking out a combo with magic runes and gadgets makes for massive fun. The game's visuals are beautiful on the 360, as well, particularly the great array of environments. Unfortunately, the game relies heavily on invisible fencing and has some awkward environmental navigation issues, often leading to frustrating situations that detract from the fun. Likewise, the game has a tough learning curve, so casual players may feel less compelled to stick with the lengthy campaign even on easier settings. Still, Assassins of Kings is a compelling, brutal ride to the dark side of fantasy no RPG fan should miss!

column13: PS3: One of the worst games I've ever played.
column14:
Short: PS3 version terrible. Do not buy.

Controls badly done, graphics muddy and PS2-like, slow long load times.

Long:

I get the impression the PC version of this game was good. This review is for the PS3 version, which is clearly an outsourced, probably offshore port, and horribly, horribly done. Do not buy the PS3 version. The game's gameplay is very confused - you use X to attack, pick stuff up, and talk to your fellow party members.

That's a problem, because your party members are constantly around you, ready to talk, even when you're doing stuff. If you make the mistake of turning their way and hitting that one universal button, the game freezes while it loads up the conversation screen, and the character asks what you'd like to talk about. There is no Cancel button so you must then carefully navigate the conversation to get out of it.

It also disarms traps, and anyone can try to disarm one at any time, even though only Rogues have a shot at succeeding. So, as an enemy beats the hell out of you, you'll hit X over and over to attack, and your character stands still with the message, "Disarm trap failed" flooding the screen, until you're beaten to death.

The graphics are muddy and look worse than some PS2 games I've played. Heck I've played better looking Super Nintendo games.

The game is insanely slow to load given how little it accomplishes. Starting it involves watching brand cutscene after cutscene, and any mode that's even slightly different involves a freeze and load time - for example moving from indoors to outdoors, between places, around a city, walking to conversation.

Probably the worst scene in the game is one where a large puzzle must be solved by shifting tiles around, that would be very easy using a mouse or, if they'd written special controls for it, even easier on the D-Pad on the gamepad. They did not, and instead you have to very carefully walk yourcharacter around the board nudging things.

It's too bad because there are some good plot twists and fun things to do like becoming a mage who can freeze somebody into an ice statue, then shapeshift into a golem and smash them in one hit. I bet that'd look really cool if they'd ported this game with any real developers whatsoever.

column14:
THINK TWICE ABOUT BUYING THIS PARTICULAR SYSTEM:
First I want to say that I love Nintendo products. I myself own the Wii U deluxe edition which came with the Super Mario 3D World and Nintendoland games pre-installed. However, this product right here is overly priced due to the fact that you can get the deluxe edition for $299 and get Super Mario 3D World and Nintendoland and plus about $50 to $60 for Mario Kart 8. We are talking about $359 with the addition that you would have an extra game. This bundle is not a limited edition so the price is too high for a bundle so simple like this one. I wouldn't recommend you buying it. In addition the gamepad's battery life can be jeopardized when the battery is not recharged every six months. This bundle came out quit a long time ago and has not been in the market transit for a while, which in turn means that you are taking the risk of getting a gamepad that is more than six months old. I would suggest you look for a better offer since there is nothing special about this bundle and the price is too high.

CONSOLE REVIEW:
For those of you who are looking for a review on the console itself: well the console is a great hit of innovation. It is fun to integrate your gamepad with some of the games like Nintendoland and Mario Kart 8, etc. However, the gamepad itself is a dust magnet, so try to already have in hand a screen protector and a jacket for your gamepad before you open the box. It is not necessary though, unless you are kind of OCD like I am. The battery life is a bit lacking for it doesn't last more than 4 - 4.5 hours of game play. There are additional larger batteries that you can buy that'll last a bit longer, but it can become hard to find them cheap. Next, the console is durable when it comes to the hardware inside and the software. I've had mine for a while and there haven't been any problems with the system. However, the console is a finger stain magnet, so right out the box you will experience this by leaving your finger prints in the console. A little damp and dry microfiber cloth will do for the cleaning of your finger prints. I would bring up the specs of the CPU and GPU speeds, but it is too much of a problem since these consoles are not given too much pressure unlike PCs where this does matter a lot. I am not giving biased opinions, for I play almost all platforms of gaming systems like PCs, XBox One, Play Station 4, and the Wii U. My opinion comes merely from the experience I've had with the system I currently have. The game titles you can buy are good. I love the new Smash Bros, Mario Kart 8, Bayonetta 2 and the old Nintendo games that you can play like The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time. I wouldn't recommend Bayonetta 2 for very young children though. Parents be aware what you buy for your children. I give the Wii U system a solid 4 stars since there are still some areas from which Nintendo should bring more the use of the gamepad, and the battery life is lacking in power. However, I give only one star to this particularly over priced system which has nothing special from the current deluxe edition you can buy for $299.

Quick and Dirty, "TL;DR") Version:

In a nutshell, the reviews do not lie. You can gain several hours OR DAYS on a single charge, and a charge is a reasonable ~4 or so hours. Yes, it adds heft and weight, but it isn't overwhelming (though if you have weak wrists or fingers it could pose a problem). You will NEED a Phillips #00 screwdriver for both the 3DS screws and the new battery screws. I played for several hours straight on a 3DS game, plus some hours in sleep mode, WiFi and 3D on the WHOLE TIME with brightness at 3 (for comfort) - lost one bar by the end of the day. Very well worth the money.

Full Review with Back Story:

I bought a used 3DS from a guy on eBay. The description said "Adult Owned" and that it came with a charger and stylus. It looked good in pictures.

Upon receiving it, it was in good overall condition but even after charging it fully, it would start flashing red and die within SECONDS, after only a couple hours of play, and even though 3D was off. It didn't leave me any time to save.

I was perplexed because no one else seemed to have as awful luck with the battery as I was having. Most of what I read said that the 3DS battery was good for only about 3 hours, but it seemed that the light was supposed to turn red for awhile, THEN flash and even then, should've at least allowed for a few minutes of time to save and get it on a charger. The best I managed was with Power Save - On, Brightness - 1, 3D off, WiFi off, playing a regular DS game. I think I got about 3-4 hours max before it shut off with only 1 or 2 flashes (almost instantaneous).

After dealing with that, I decided that the battery must have been going and so I needed to replace it if I wanted to get any portability (I mostly played on the charger).

I was instantly attracted to this battery for the long life between charges (based on reviews). I wasn't leery about "voiding my warranty" since I don't have one, and the reviews put me at ease about the possibility of the battery overcharging and killing the 3DS. I didn't want to blow a comparable amount of money on a regular, OEM replacement, affording me only the regular 3DS lifespan (considering most people in the forums complained about it only lasting a few hours). I didn't even want to get a "double the battery life" product, when the reviews for this promised MANY hours, and even DAYS. I figured worst case scenario, I would just get better time than what I was getting, best case - tons of extra time.

I bought mine from MPF (on Amazon), because it was cheaper than the one with free Prime shipping and they said that they provided a screwdriver tool.

They did, but it did not work. I don't say that to deter you from buying from them but rather because you will still need a #00 Phillips. This is a pretty specific screwdriver and the cheapo jeweler/eyeglass sets generally do NOT appear to contain them (I'd bought one, but ended up taking it back). I found mine at Ace Hardware, but I would suggest just finding one on Amazon or eBay and ordering it at the same time as you order the battery. The only #00 Philips I found were parts of sets that cost over $10, but I saw singles online for $4.

Once I finally got the back off, I discovered why my battery life was so terrible and why the flashing was so abrupt (with no regular red light to warn you). The eBay seller had completely neglected to mention that the battery was some cheap knockoff! I was worried while considering my purchase of this battery about using a non-Nintendo product - and here there was already one installed. It didn't even fit properly in the 3DS as there were folded pieces of paper keeping it snug.

On the other hand, the new battery fit perfectly, but since it is so much more capacity, it's also so much more battery. It covers the whole back, hence it comes with its own cover and screws (shiny dark gray/black). The screws are TINY - literally about the size of ants. Again, you will NEED a Phillips #00.

Once I got it installed, I kept the 3DS off and put it on the charger. I left it charging for several hours After around 3 hours, I tried what other reviewers have done and unplugged it and plugged it back in. Light stayed orange. (My boyfriend actually remarked that the charge light appeared to glow brighter with the new battery.) I plugged it back in and checked again (same method) after another hour. This time, the orange light went off a moment after plugging it back in.

I took it off the charger and started playing. The weight difference was noticeable immediately, and the grasp was a little different. I turned the brightness up to 3, and turned the 3D up all the way. Kept WiFi on, volume up about halfway (no headphones). I did keep power saver on, but only for the apparent blue light reduction. Played from 5:20pm to 6:45pm. Put it in sleep mode with WiFi on.

Came back to it around 8pm. Played until about 11pm using the same settings as above. Still had full battery when I went to bed.

I went to sleep and put it on the charger overnight. When I woke up, the orange light had gone off automatically, as it has all subsequent nights. I am guessing that the orange light just takes longer to go off on this battery?

I decided to test the battery more, and I was still amazed at the new portability. I took it off the charger around 11:30am. I played off and on several hours throughout the day (WiFi on, volume up, 3D up at times but not the entire time). Had it in sleep mode in between. Decided to even watch a 1.5 hour movie on it on Netflix. By the end of the day, I had finally managed to lose 1 bar.

Overall, this is an incredible buy. I have always charged it at night, but I could see it easily lasting several days - particularly if you aren't playing for several hours at a time.

The weight and added thickness *are* noticeable, but unless you are playing for hours and hours on end, I don't think it would be too much. My wrists would give out before this battery would, but I think my desire to play would give out before my wrists would.

I also was worried that after all the time playing, it might get hot (as some reviewers mentioned with other 3rd party batteries). It did not. It barely felt warm at all, so I don't feel like I'm going to damage my 3DS with it in any way.

My 3DS is black so the back being black doesn't matter but I would think the aesthetic difference would be worth the additional play time.

If you own a 3DS, even if you have a real Nintendo battery in there, you can't go wrong with this. My 3DS is black so the back being black doesn't matter but I would think the aesthetic difference would be worth the additional play time.

If you own a 3DS, even if you have a real Nintendo battery in there, you can't go wrong with this. Not only could you manage full length flights, it could go on camping trips and probably survive several days on a full charge with moderate play. I almost regretted buying the 3DS (not knowing it was a knockoff battery) but this changed my mind!
